text:
Willy And The Poorboys (Fantasy, 1969), un concept dedicato alla classe proletaria, fece leva su canzoni meno ossessive e su testi piu` realisti. Le standout sono Down On The Corner, quadriglia sincopata e caraibica, e Fortunate Son, primo dei loro tre grandi rock and roll acrobatici.
Cosmo's Factory (Fantasy, 1970), probabilmente il loro capolavoro, punta fin da Ramble Tamble sulle cadenze viscerali e trascinanti del blues del Delta e sulle atmosfere inquietanti dei rituali della jungla. Nasce cosi` Run Thru The Jungle, l'incubo piu` tetro e ipnotico della loro carriera. Ma il gruppo ha raggiunto la maturita` nel reinterpretare la tradizione e lo dimostra con Travelin' Band, secondo dei loro grandi rock and roll, Looking Out My Backdoor, ragtime orecchiabile ed effervescente, Up Around The Bend, ruggente shout a ritmo boogie, e Who'll Stop The Rain, gospel accelerato su un incalzante jingle-jangle.
trans:
Willy And The Poorboys (Fantasy, 1969), a concept album dedicated to the proletarian class, leaned on less obsessive songs and more realistic lyrics. The standout tracks are Down On The Corner, syncopated and Caribbean quadrille, and Fortunate Son, the first of their three great rock and roll acrobatics.
Cosmo's Factory (Fantasy, 1970), probably their masterpiece, has been based on the visceral and gripping cadences of the blues of the Delta and eerie atmospheres of the rituals of the jungle since Ramble Ramble. This gave rise to Run Thru The Jungle, the darkest and most hypnotic nightmare of their career. Yet the group showed its maturity in reinterpreting tradition, as evidenced by Travelin’ Band, the second of their great rock and roll hits, Looking Out My Backdoor, a catchy and effervescent ragtime, Up Around The Bend, a roaring boogie-paced shout, and Who’ll Stop The Rain, accelerated on a pressing jingle-jingle.
